abstract: |
  To what extent has humanity degraded ecosystems? This is a crucial question we need to ask ourselves if we are to reconcile our relationship with nature and imagine a more desirable future. Although everyone has heard anecdotal accounts of once-abundant species from previous generations, systematic quantification of ecosystem degradation over time is difficult to achieve due to limited historical data. Instead, it is possible to use the most pristine ecosystems known today to estimate the lower bound of our current impact on nature. By measuring 22 potential contributions of fish communities to nature and people in over 2000 tropical reefs, we have explored the impact of anthropogenic activities and conservation measures on fish communities. By explaining these contributions by more than 40 environmental, habitat and human covariates, we conducted counterfactual scenarios on unprotected and protected reefs to measure the effect of anthropogenic activities and conservation measures on contributions to Nature and People. We show that anthropogenic activities have massively reduced the biomass and diversity of fish communities on tropical reefs, reducing the total measured contributions by an average of 10%. Despite a non-negligible impact on biomass and IUCN species richness, conservation efforts to date have only been able to offset the decline by a few percent. Our results show that despite the undoubted benefits of current protected areas, reef protection cannot and will not compensate for all our extraction, pollution and ecosystem destruction. A change in our relationship with nature is therefore urgent and imperative if we are to imagine an enviable future for nature and people.
  
  
  
  
    **What is the impact of human activities on ecosystems, (compared with known minimum impact conditions)?**
    **Given current human populations, what gains have protected areas brought?**
    
    *Other idea: The global deficit of fish contributions to nature and people on impacted coral reefs*

# Results

## Method summary

- RLS data -> assessment of potential community contributions in each reef (i.e. at the **_site level_**: a GPS point at a given date): 2483 RLS sampled sites in tropical regions (see @fig-map), 22 contributions to Nature and People. (Inference of missing species traits to take into account most of the RLS sites, cf Methods)

- Socio-environnemental data: 39 covariates of environment, habitat, and anthropic activities. (Inference of the missing data in benthic compositions (~30%) by Missforest )

- Each RLS site is categorized according to its level of protection. Out of the 2483 sites, we had 655 out of reserve (no conservation measures), 1297 restricted mpa (all conservation measures), 531 full MPAs (no take mpa with high to medium compliance), spread over 33 countries.

- Use of a Bayesian hierarchical model (Hmsc) to estimate the expected community contributions under different human pressure conditions, accounting for other habitat and environmental variables: use of the 39 covariates as linear fixed effects, **country** and **site_code levels** are used as random factors as *(1|site_code/country)*. 

::: {.callout-note}
HMSC (Hierarchical Modeling of Species Communities) is a jSDM that relies on a latent variable approach to estimate the residual covariance matrix (Tikhonov, Opedal et al., 2020).

"In a multivariate model it is possible to define a random effect at the sampling unit level, as in a multivariate case the random effect models not only variation within species, but also co-variation among species, i.e. species-to-species residual associations."
:::



## Inference of contributions

### Model performance: half of contributions can be inferred with r² over 0.74 {.unnumbered}

  + Good convergence of the model with thin = 2000, samples = 100, chains = 2: effective sample size around Nsamples * Nchains (see @fig-convergence), and good chain convergence (see @fig-chains).
  
  + Good explanatory power of the full model with mean_r² = 0.69 (from 0.24 for calcium to 1 for available biomass), and a satisfying predictive power in a 5-fold crossvalidation with mean_r² = 0.33 (from 0.08 for calcium to 0.9 for mean endemism) (see @fig-power).
  
  + The full model outperformed the null model (only with random levels) which has an average predictive power of r² = 0.24 (see @fig-power_null).
  

### Partitioning of explained variance: strong influence of ecological histories {.unnumbered}

![**Variance partitioning of the full model.** *The total height of each bar correspond to the percent of the initial variance explained by the model (R² for each response variable).The importance of the covariates in the explained variance is represented by the height of the stacked bars.* ](img/variance_partitioning_absolute_values_test_mpa2_FULL_model_SITE_SCALE_2_chains_2000_thin_100_samples.jpg){#fig-VP_full_model width=100%}



**&rarr; Observations:**

  + High importance of random levels. In average, 68.4% of the explained variance, 48.3% of the initial variance (see @fig-VP_full_model and @fig-VP_agreg).
  
    - the potentially different intercepts for each random factor provide good explanatory power, as the random factors behave like latent variables (reproducing missing variables), but we couldn't find obvious spatial pattern in latent variables (see @fig-latent).
    
    - then, local effects seem very important, with contributions depending strongly on local contingencies. Much is determined by location: either because of the importance of the reef's **ecological history** (species biogeography, particular past geological or ecological events, a local fishing method, a specific tradition of local populations,...), or because of **local interactions** between contributions (co-occurrence or inherent trade-offs due to micro-habitats, the presence of a coral type, a keystone species, ...). Mean_endemism, functional_distinctiveness, omega_3, and evolutionary_distinctiveness are examples of contributions where the country random levels explain a high proportion of the variance, because these contributions are caracterized by large geographical patterns due to geological history or latitudinal gradients. Conversely, the contributions relating to biomass show a strong effect of the random sampling_unit factor, as they probably depend more on local factors and are more likely to co-occur.
    
     
  
  + At the global scale, we explain 31.6% of the explained variance (i.e. 20.8% of the initial variance) with fixed effects.
    
      - in average: 11.5% explained by environment, 10.3% by human variables, and 9.8% by habitat (@fig-VP_agreg), with median SST over 5 years, and the human gravity as the two most influential drivers of contributions. (@fig-imp_variable).
      
      - Among the environmental variables, *SST*, *chlorophyll* and *salinity* are the three most important because they deeply affect fish communities. Among the human variables, *gravity*, *marine ecosystem dependency* and *hdi* are the three most important variables, as they must correspond to the degree and type of anthropogenic pressure applied to the communities. Among the habitat variables, the depth and area of terrestrial reef flat within a 500m radius are the most important, as they must correspond to the amount of space available for the communities.
      
      - In average, the MPAs protection_status explains only 1% of the variance in contributions.

**&rarr; Observations:**

  + Among human covariates, gravity is the most important variables (~2.5% of the explianed variance, @fig-imp_variable). The presence of large population close from the reef (i.e. high gravity) has a strong negative influence on piscivores and available biomass, trophic web robustness and IUCN species (@fig-ridge_estimates). On the contrary, gravity has a positive effect on biomass turnover, aesthetics and evolutionary distinctiveness, as some areas with large populations, such as the Caribbean, constitute areas with a particular evolutionary history, have a low biomass that is rapidly renewed due to human exploitation, and feature relatively attractive fish communities.
  
  + Although reef protection explains only 1% of the explained variance, we found a positive effect on community aesthetics and public attention, available, invertivores and herbivores biomass, as well as species richness and the presence of IUCN species (see @fig-heatmap-estimates-hmsc  to see the support level of each estimates). ...
  
  + ...


**&rarr; Residual associations between contributions: **

  + Mantel test between residual association matrix and initial contribution correlation matrix (@fig-residual_asso). Mantel statistic r=0.64: the same patterns of covariations are preserved, i.e. we couldn't explain all covariations by fixed and random effects => importance of ecological history of sites, or inherent co-occurrence and trade-offs. 

 + By using the full set of non-focal “species” (21 other contributions) to individually predict each contribution at new sites, it is possible to evaluate the full information contained in the residual association matrix (cf Vallé 2024). We show that prediction qualities are greatly improved in conditional predictions (see @fig-power), indicating that the residual association matrix does not reflect noise, or model misspecification (Tikhonov, 2018).

## Counterfactual scenarios

In the end, we have only a few levers available at political level to increase contributions. But here, our levers are unbiased and we can examine what we can expect in the various contexts we observe today -> counterfactual scenarios.

These aren't really predictive scenarios, because we don't know the “activation energy” required to move from one evolutive path to another: we have to take into account the inertia of ecosystems. Here, we're measuring the “**ecological deficit of protection**”, i.e. what we'd have now if we'd protected all the sites (with the current level/efficiency of protection of our sites). -> Taking action now should take us in these directions, but we can't say how long it will take/ how easy it will be to reach these states. This kind of modeling helps to show what average gain we can expect.

**&rarr; Observations:**

  +   Worldwide, a high level of protection in unprotected sites could bring an average increase of 3.9% in contributions, with significant variability between contributions (from -3.5% for the biomass turnover to +24.7% for the herbivore biomass) and very high variability between sites (@fig-conterfactuals). Overall, fish biomass and species richness would benefit the most from such protection, with an average gain of 14% in available biomass and 8% in actinopterygii richness. We also note a very strong gain of 20% in the presence of IUCN species, but with considerable variability, suggesting a strong contextual effect. The same contextual variability is found for piscivorous fish.
  
  
  
**&rarr; Observations:**

  + We observed that all countries have similar responses to anthropogenic activities, with tropical reef communities generally richer in species, biomass, aesthetics, etc. if they are placed in conditions of high protection and low anthropogenic pressure (@fig-counterfactuals (A)). 
  
  + However, we can see that these changes in contributions are largely influenced by the presence of human populations, in relation to reef protection (@fig-counterfactuals (B) and (C)). We see that the total protection of unprotected sites would result in a 16% of available biomass, whereas the reduction of anthropic pressure would let a 42% increase (see @fig-percent_change for changes in percent).

# Materials and methods

## Filtering RLS data
-> Figure for the method workflow ?

##### __Extract fish abundance assessement from RLS protocol, filter misidentifications, duplicates, and observations without fish__ {.unnumbered}

- select “method 1, block 1 and 2” in RLS metadata (fish assessment in 2 bands of 5mx50m)

- Remove all observations with misidentifications: “spp.”, “sp.”, “(cf)”, “hybrid”, “Unidentified”, “?”, “!”, “/”, “New”, “green form”

- Same information recorded twice, by two different divers (same survey ID, block, species, total, and size) -> keep only one observation for each.

- remove line with total = 0


##### __filter fishes difficult to spot consistently with UVC__ {.unnumbered}

-Remove Elasmobranchs from abundance data (different behaviours, shy or not, ...)

-Remove anguiliforms: 16 families according to WORMS: c( "Anguillidae", "Chlopsidae", "Colocongridae", "Congridae" , "Derichthyidae" , "Heterenchelyidae" , "Moringuidae" , "Muraenesocidae" , "Muraenidae" , "Myrocongridae" , "Nemichthyidae" , "Nettastomatidae" , "Ophichthidae" , "Protanguillidae" , "Serrivomeridae" , "Synaphobranchidae")

-Remove cryptobenthic families: c("Aploactinidae", "Apogonidae", "Blenniidae", 
                     "Bythitidae", "Callionymidae", "Chaenopsidae", 
                     "Creediidae", "Dactyloscopidae", "Gobiesocidae", 
                     "Gobiidae", "Grammatidae", "Labrisomidae", 
                     "Opistognathidae", "Plesiopidae", "Pseudochromidae", 
                     "Syngnathidae", "Tripterygiidae")




##### __Checking size__ {.unnumbered}
-Filling values in Maximum length data: missing values are completed by applying the mean of the genus or the family (if no species in the same genus)

-Remove juveniles: all fish of 2.5 cm, and fish of 5 cm if the maximum length of the species is > 25 cm

-Remove abnormal size estimation:  fish with a max length < 3.75, individuals for which size_class > 2*(Maximum length) or (Maximum length+50) => __we removed all the surveys with size_class errors__.


##### __Filter outliers surveys__ {.unnumbered}
To avoid over-estimating fish abundance due to temporary fish aggregations or large roaming schools, we excluded **surveys** with a total **biomass over 500 kg/500m²** or an **abundance exceeding 10,000 individuals**.


##### __Elasmobranch data__ {.unnumbered}
All Elasmobranch occurences are kept for the **surveys** meeting all the above conditions (Elamsobranch abundance isn't used)





## Species traits

##### __Species list__ {.unnumbered}

We consider only surveys that experience a minimum monthly sea surface temperature (SST) above 17°C, over the 5 years before the sampling protocol (survey date).
+We consider only surveys between -30° and 30° of latitude to fit with the habitat variables of the Allen Atlas.
We extracted all species ('rls_species_name') found in the remaining surveys.

```{r, echo=FALSE}
load(file = here::here("data/derived_data/tropical_species_traits.Rdata"))
elasmo <- nrow(dplyr::filter(tropical_species_traits, class == "Elasmobranchii"))
actino <- nrow(tropical_species_traits) - elasmo
```

Overall, we consider the abundance data of __`r actino` actinopterygians__ and the occurence data of __`r elasmo` elasmobranchs__.



##### __Traits and databases__ {.unnumbered}

We extracted species traits from fishbase and others sources, to assess the contributions of each individuas. See supplementary for the table of traits.


##### __Merge traits__ {.unnumbered}

To avoid taxonomic mismatch, we associated the species name of all databases and RLS data, with the accepted scientific name of rfishbase and its SpecCode (unique ID). All data base have been then merged using this unique ID.

##### __Traits inference__ {.unnumbered}

Assess the performance of missforest on prediction:
On 100 iterations, we create a trait dataset with 20% of NAs randomly placed. We used MissForest package (ntree = 100, max_iter = 10) to infer the created missing values and evaluated the prediction performance.
Categorical variables were evaluate with accuracy (proportion of good prediction) and numerical variables were evaluated with R-squared correlation, over the 100 iterations. 
<!--The expected proportion of error in our final dataset was calculated as the proportion of missing values multiplied by the potential error of missforest ( Prop_NA * (1-R²) ).
We choose to fill gaps on variables with *reasonable risk of error* .-->
To fill the gaps, we ran 100 missforest models on the dataset and check the consistency of all models. Categorical values were kept if more than 80% of models converged to the same result. The median of the 100 numerical values were kept if the coefficient of variation (sd/mean) < 0.2, i.e if 1-CV > 0.8.


##### __Targeted families__ {.unnumbered}

Fish families were classified at the word scale as fished (targeted), not fished (untargerted), or fished if species can reach 20cm (targeted > 20cm). See Supplementary for the list of families and the classification.


## Contributions assessement

Cf "*Fish communities can simultaneously contribute to nature and people across the world’s tropical reefs*", Flandrin *et al.* 2024, One Earth.

We assessed the potential contribution of a surveys only if the species for which the needed traits are still unknown represent less than 20% of the abundance and 20% of biomass of the survey.

We removed carbonate estimates and recycling because there were too much unknown values. Elamsobranch richness has been replaced by IUCN species. IUCN assessement for actinopterygians was extracted from Loiseau et. al 2024. Species aesthetic values from Langlois et al. 2022 were completed with knew species in RLS database following the same framework. Same for public attention from Mouquet et al. 2024.
All contributions were scaled, and surveys with NAs were removed. Site contributions were assessed as the mean of survey contributions of a given date.

##### __Inference of benthic composition__ {.unnumbered}

30% of missing values in RLS phoquadrats.
Missforest, using coordinates avec the 20 first axis of a PCoA of all covariates.
<!--
Benthic composition is assessed during RLS surveys using photo-quadrats of the substrate. Twenty evenly-spaced photos are recorded along the survey transect and later processed using SQUIDLE+ software (https://squidle.org/). Points are randomly overlaid on photographs and users identify the organisms into broad functional groups (and sometimes to the lowest taxonomic resolution possible) that the points land on. This provides percent cover data for benthic organisms such as corals, macroalgae, sponges, etc. Here, we binned the groups into 9 broader benthic groups that can be consistently applied (globally): coral, algae, coralline algae, seagrass, other sessile invertebrates (e.g., ascidians, sponges), coral rubble, rock, sand, and microalgal mats (e.g., cyanobacteria, encrusting algae films). We first applied an arcsine transformation (inverse Sine of square-root transformed values) to the proportional benthic cover data, which were highly right skewed. This is similar to a log transformation but more appropriate for proportional data, which are bounded between 0 and 1 **[REF]**. 
In the tropical zone, we used the available socio-environnmentales covariates to infer the 29% of missing values on benthic composition.
We first applied a PCoA on these covariates, except spatial information (latitude, longitude, depth), to reduce 63 variables into 20 composite dimensions. We then used these 20+3 spatial dimensions to infer the arcsine transformed benthic composition.
We tested the accuracy of the imputation by cross validation with the observed data. We randomly deleted 30% of true observations, imputed those values, and checked the correlation between the true and the imputed values. Correlations were reasonably good for all categories (R-squares between 0.4 and 0.7), with very good predictions for algae and coral cover (R-squares ~0.7 for each).

##### __Selection and preping of covariates__ {.unnumbered}

+ Environment: we kept the median, quantiles 5% and 95% over the last 5 years before the sampling, of nppv, chl, DHW, SST, pH, so, O2.

+ Habitat: Allen Atlas in a area of 500m of diameter, and local habitats from benthic cover.

+ Human: all we had.

We then removed variables that were highly correlated (pearson correlation > 0.7) + VIF analysis: VIF < 5.

Covariates with right-skewed distribution have been log-transformed, and then all covariates have been scaled (mean = 0, sd = 1)





## Hmsc: Hierarchical Model of Species Communities (Bayesian model)

-> "HMSC quantifies the explained variation within the observed communities through included fixed covariates, as well as through random effects, which can account for e.g. patterns arising from spatiotemporal processes. However, HMSC may include random factors that can be linked to species-specific co-occurrence patterns within the unexplained (residual) variation. These random effects are shown through either positive or negative pair-wise species associations reflecting ecological processes that take place in addition to species’ responses to the environment (e.g. dispersal limitation, biotic interactions, and random level specific covariates not captured by the fixed effects)."

-> multivariate response: take into account the associations between contributions: Random level at the sampling unit

-> we set **countries** and **sampling unit** as a random effects to account for the spatial structure of the data and potential co-occurences of contributions (interactions).

-> We fitted a normal HMSC model for all contributions because most contributions show normal distributions (@fig-distr-contrib) and this gave the best prediction levels.

-> All contributions and covariates were log-transformed when they had right-skewed contributions, ad all contributions and covariates have been scaled to a mean of 0 and unit variance over the columns

-> Give posterior distributions of estimates and the explained variance partitioning.

-> Check Convergence, model performance and sensibility analysis: see supplementary.

##### __Targeted families__ {.unnumbered}

Determine if species are targeted or not at the family level, from fishbase data:

```{r, echo=FALSE, eval=FALSE}
targeted_species <- targeted_species |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    target = ifelse(mean_importance_of_family %in%c("highly commercial",
                                                    "commercial",
                                                    "subsistence fisheries"), "targeted",
              ifelse(mean_importance_of_family == "of no interest", "untargeted",
                ifelse(max_MaxLength_of_family < 20, "untargeted", 
                  ifelse(max_importance_of_family %in% c("highly commercial",
                                                         "commercial"), "targeted>20cm", 
                    ifelse(is.na(target) & 
                           mean_importance_of_family == "minor commercial", "targeted>20cm", "untargeted"))))))
```
